Award.AwardTitle: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research: Integrated Analysis of Freshwater Resources Sustainability in Jordan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support to U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 13-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum and the G8 countries Heads of Research Councils. The Belmont Forum is a high level group of the world's major and emerging funders of global environmental change research and international science councils. It aims to accelerate delivery of the international environmental research most urgently needed to remove critical barriers to sustainability by aligning and mobilizing international resources. The G8 Heads of Research Councils developed a funding framework to support multilateral research projects that address global challenges in ways that are beyond the capacity of national or bilateral activities. Each partner country provides funding for their researchers within a consortium to alleviate the need for funds to cross international borders. This approach facilitates effective leveraging of national resources to support excellent research on topics of global relevance best tackled through a multinational approach, recognizing that global challenges need global solutions.

Working together in an inaugural call of the International Opportunities Fund, the Belmont Forum and G8HORCs have provided support for research projects that seek to deliver knowledge needed for action to mitigate and adapt to detrimental environmental change and extreme hazardous events that relate to either Freshwater Security or Coastal Vulnerability. This award provides support for the U.S. researchers to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., policy makers, regulators, NGOs, communities and industry).

This award supports research activities that will develop a framework to understand and evaluate water management options and strategies in water-stressed countries using Jordan as a model state. Jordan has one of the lowest water resources availability and is the heart of Middle East trans-boundary water issues, making it representative of many physical and social structures that can lead to widespread freshwater security challenges. Existing models typically neglect interactions and feedbacks between hydrological and socioeconomic systems, thereby limiting the ability to understand the implications and feedbacks of long term management strategies and water availability changes. This project will develop quantitative evaluation tools to explore ways to enhance sustainability of freshwater systems through a variety of social and economic mechanisms. Models will incorporate both natural processes and human decision making and management criteria. These efforts will be used to evaluate a wide range of freshwater management options. This work will contribute new tools to understand and forecast water management strategies and feedbacks between natural and social systems. The project will involve a range of government agencies, civil organizations and research institutes to strengthen individual and institutional capacity of the water sector in Jordan, with implications for water management strategies in water stressed states everywhere.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Jordan Water Project (JWP) was a Belmont Forum interdisciplinary collaboration involving teams of natural scientists, social scientists and engineers in the United States, Germany, Canada, and the United Kingdom, with Jordanian participation supported through the NSF-PEER program (USAID). With tremendous cooperation and data supplied by Jordan's Ministry of Water and Irrigation, plus satellite remote sensing data, we constructed a suite of process-based models that were coupled to enable evaluation of long-term impacts of policies to improve water security in Jordan.

Our integrated model captures the essential features of the human-engineered-natural system in the presence of rapid environmental and socioeconomic changes. This novel approach simulates the behavior of Jordan?s surface water and groundwater systems within the context of competing and interacting interests of governmental, agricultural, industrial, and municipal agents. The (multi-agent) integrated model was run under a series of narratives describing various futures in Jordan involving interventions ranging from new water supply infrastructure to higher water tariffs, and scenarios accounting for future climate and population changes. Results suggest that all projected supply enhancement projects are vital to prevent a future nationwide freshwater crisis. However, there is also tremendous opportunity to enhance water security by implementing demand-side interventions combined with transferring water from agriculture to cities, and reducing water theft and conveyance losses.

Besides our integrated multi-agent model, during the course of this project we developed several methods and produced results having significant intellectual merit. 1) We constructed high resolution climate-change projections coupled with hydrologic simulations to evaluate three types of future droughts: meteorological (rainfall decrease), agricultural (soil moisture deficit), and hydrologic (streamflow decline). Comparing model results for the periods 1980-2010 to 2070-2100, average temperature increases by 4.5 degrees C, rainfall decreases by 30%, and multiple drought-type occurrences increase from ~8 in 30 years to ~25 in 30 years. 2) We developed a new method that enables satellite remote sensing to greatly improved estimates of crop water use. This is important to monitor unlicensed groundwater extraction used for irrigation. 3) Coupling satellite remote sensing and hydrologic simulation, we quantified how the Syrian refugee crisis of 2011 and the consequent reduction in agricultural irrigation in Syria affected transboundary river flows to Jordan. 4) Using hydrologic simulation, remote sensing, and game-theory, we explored the influences of communal groundwater being extracted by both Saudi Arabia and Jordan and showed how the near-term transboundary impacts are being avoided by preserving a near-border no-pumping buffer zone between the two countries. 5) We conducted a global analysis that evaluated a series of 19 metrics of freshwater vulnerability comparing 119 lower per capita income countries. Vulnerabilities fell into four broad categories: endowment, demand, infrastructure, and institutions. Results show that all of these nations experience some form of vulnerability, with institutional vulnerability experienced most commonly, occurring in 44 nations. Jordan was among the most water-vulnerable countries. In addition, we studied vulnerability of 70 large cities in 39 countries that were dependent on surface water for their supply. We found that 36% of these cities are vulnerable as they compete with agriculture for their supply, increasing to 44% by 2040.

Several of our approaches and analyses have had a significant impact within the scholarly fields covered by our work. This conclusion is supported by the appearance of citations of our published papers, the number of paper downloads (over 20,000 for just three of our publications), and receipt of the Best Paper Award in 2015 for our article, Global analysis of urban surface water supply vulnerability, in Environmental Research Letters (ERL). Overall, the JWP trained four students and postdocs who are now faculty at other institutions, and two in government scientist positions.

Our efforts have had a broader impact on advancing analysis of freshwater resources and water security. Owing to our interdisciplinary approach and team of natural scientists, social scientists and engineers, our project impact has gone beyond that of any single field of interest. The project resulted in the first comprehensive nationwide policy-evaluation tool that integrates rigorous descriptions of human-engineered-natural freshwater systems. By accounting for feedbacks and interactions that cross traditional disciplinary boundaries, we have developed insights and a quantitative, transdisciplinary understanding of Jordan's freshwater resources and its potentially grim future.

Our systems model provides Jordan with significant new capability to evaluate future water supply infrastructure and water tariffs, and scenarios accounting for future droughts, land-use change, economic development, and population changes that include the potential influx of additional refugees. By working closely with Jordans Ministry of Water and Irrigation, our coupled-process systems model has been well received by Jordans water sector leaders. They recognize that evaluating future policy interventions before those strategies are implemented will be of great benefit to reducing freshwater vulnerability and enhancing long-term sustainability. The approach developed during this project has significant transfer value to other regions having present and future freshwater vulnerability.
